elements.content: A mixed-ligand, partially fluorinated, 2-periodic metal–organic framework [Zn­(hfipbb)­(bpt)] n ­·n(DMF)2­·n(H2O) (1) has been synthesized from the unique combination of a V-shaped dicarboxylic acid ligand, H2hfipbb = 4,4′-(hexafluoroisopropylidene)­bis­(benzoic acid) and a bent pyridyl based colinker, bpt = 4-amino-3,5-bis­(4-pyridyl)-1,2,4-triazole. This framework undergoes single-crystal-to-single-crystal solvent exchange that leads to the formation of four additional structures [Zn­(hfipbb)­(bpt)] n ­·n(EtOH)2 (2), [Zn­(hfipbb)­(bpt)] n ­·n(DCM)2­·n(H2O) (3), [Zn­(hfipbb)­(bpt)] n ­·n(DMA)2­·n(H2O)2 (4), and [Zn­(hfipbb)­(bpt)] n ­·n(H2O)3 (5). The solvent-induced “breathing” of the 2-periodic frameworks results in potential void spaces varying from 15.2 to 35.4%, resulting mainly from the conformational twisting and ligation angle of the bpt ligand accompanied by rotation of the carboxylate group of the hfipbb ligand causing a change from mono- to bidentate ligation. Variable-temperature powder X-ray diffraction shows that removal of solvent from three frameworks (1, 2, and 3) led to the same desolvated phase. The activated phase shows appreciable carbon dioxide sorption at 195 K and hydrogen at 77 K, as well as water vapor at 298 K.

elements.content: Metal–organic frameworks (MOFs) or porous coordination polymers (PCPs), composed of metal ions and organic bridging ligands, have emerged as a promising class of materials, especially in terms of gas sorption and storage studies because of their high specific surface areas, tunable structures and functionalities, high degrees of crystallinity, uniform pore sizes, and high degrees of porosity. MOFs most often contain solvent as guest molecules upon synthesis and have been classified according to the effect on their structures when these guest molecules are evacuated. First-generation MOF structures collapse irreversibly, while second-generation MOF structures are robust to the exit and entry of guest molecules. The frameworks of third-generation MOFs, due to their inherent flexibility, adapt to the presence or absence of guest molecules (or to other external stimuli such as heat and light) and have been classified as “breathing” MOFs. This breathing behavior may occur without the breaking or formation of new metal coordination bonds; however, in rarer instances the breaking or formation of new metal coordination bonds occur. The latter may prove useful in gas sorption as coordinatively unsaturated metal sites are created which may possibly aid in the sorption of gas molecules. In studying the breathing behavior of MOFs, single-crystal-to-single-crystal (SCSC) transformation phenomena have proven to be invaluable, since these provide insight into the mechanisms of breathing by elucidation of the “before” and “after” structures. MIL-53, a 3-periodic chromium­(III)-based MOF, is the archetypal MOF exhibiting breathing behavior with a change in one pore dimension of >5 Å between hydrated and dehydrated states. Two-periodic MOFs, with stacked or interdigitated layers, have also been shown to exhibit breathing behavior through the shifting of layers with respect to each other. Mixed-ligand MOFs contain more than one type of ligand and offer the possibility of increased tailoring of structural features, such as chemical functionality or pore dimensions along particular directions. Relatively recently, fluorine-functionalized organic linkers have been employed to possibly provide preferred gas sorption sites through polar C–F bonds, and in particular ligands with trifluoromethyl groups have been found to not only improve carbon dioxide sorption but also to improve their selectivity over nitrogen. The bent ligand, 4-amino-3,5-bis­(4-pyridyl)-1,2,4-triazole (bpt), is a versatile N-donor ligand that has been used in many MOF structures; however, it has not yet been combined with a fluorinated ligand in a mixed-ligand MOF.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) or porous coordination polymers (PCPs), composed of metal ions and organic bridging ligands, have emerged as a promising class of materials, especially in terms of gas sorption and storage studies because of their high specific surface areas, tunable structures and functionalities, high degrees of crystallinity, uniform pore sizes, and high degrees of porosity. MOFs most often contain solvent as guest molecules upon synthesis and have been classified according to the effect on their structures when these guest molecules are evacuated. First-generation MOF structures collapse irreversibly, while second-generation MOF structures are robust to the exit and entry of guest molecules. The frameworks of third-generation MOFs, due to their inherent flexibility, adapt to the presence or absence of guest molecules (or to other external stimuli such as heat and light) and have been classified as "breathing" MOFs. This breathing behavior may occur without the breaking or formation of new metal coordination bonds; however, in rarer instances the breaking or formation of new metal coordination bonds occur. The latter may prove useful in gas sorption as coordinatively unsaturated metal sites are created which may possibly aid in the sorption of gas molecules. In studying the breathing behavior of MOFs, single-crystal-to-single-crystal (SCSC) transformation phenomena have proven to be invaluable, since these provide insight into the mechanisms of breathing by elucidation of the "before" and "after" structures. MIL-53, a 3-periodic chromium(III)-based MOF, is the archetypal MOF exhibiting breathing behavior with a change in one pore dimension of >5 Å between hydrated and dehydrated states. Two-periodic MOFs, with stacked or interdigitated layers, have also been shown to exhibit breathing behavior through the shifting of layers with respect to each other. Mixed-ligand MOFs contain more than one type of ligand and offer the possibility of increased tailoring of structural features, such as chemical functionality or pore dimensions along particular directions. Relatively recently, fluorine-functionalized organic linkers have been employed to possibly provide preferred gas sorption sites through polar C-F bonds, and in particular ligands with trifluoromethyl groups have been found to not only improve carbon dioxide sorption but also to improve their selectivity over nitrogen. The bent ligand, 4-amino-3,5-bis(4-pyridyl)-1,2,4-triazole (bpt), is a versatile N-donor ligand that has been used in many MOF structures; however, it has not yet been combined with a fluorinated ligand in a mixed-ligand MOF.

elements.content: In this work, we report the synthesis and characterization of a novel 2-periodic, porous, mixed-ligand MOF [Zn­(hfipbb)­(bpt)] n ­·n(DMF)2­·n(H2O) (1) from the unique combination of the V-shaped ligands, H2hfipbb = 4,4′-(hexafluoroisopropylidene)­bis­(benzoic acid) and a pyridyl-based colinker, bpt = 4-amino-3,5-bis­(4-pyridyl)-1,2,4-triazole. The trifluoromethyl groups of the hfipbb ligand provide sites for increased gas sorption, while the bpt ligand incorporates flexibility into the MOF framework to facilitate its breathing behavior. This flexibility allows the 2-periodic framework to be responsive to solvent exchange with ethanol, dichloromethane, and dimethylacetamide leading to [Zn­(hfipbb)­(bpt)] n ­·n(EtOH)2 (2), [Zn­(hfipbb)­(bpt)] n ­·n(DCM)2­·n(H2O) (3), and [Zn­(hfipbb)­(bpt)] n ­·n(DMA)2­·n(H2O)2 (4), respectively, while crystals of 3 can also lead to [Zn­(hfipbb)­(bpt)] n ­·n­(H2O)3 (5), a partially hydrated form. These solvent exchanges all occur via SCSC transformations and show a large change in cavity size. Structures of the MOFs were elucidated by single crystal X-ray studies and further characterized by powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) and thermogravimetric analysis (TGA). The evacuated framework of 1 showed substantial adsorption for carbon dioxide over nitrogen and also showed appreciable sorption of water.

elements.content: All reagents and solvents, including 4,4′-(hexafluoroisopropylidene)­bis­(benzoic acid) (H2hfipbb) and Zn­(NO3)2·6H2O, were purchased from Sigma-Aldrich except for 4-amino-3,5-bis­(4-pyridyl)-1,2,4-triazole (bpt), which was prepared following a literature procedure. Solvents were not dried and may thus contain some water.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Materials and Physical Measurements

All reagents and solvents, including 4,4'-(hexafluoroisopropylidene)bis(benzoic acid) (H2hfipbb) and Zn(NO3)2⋅6H2O, were purchased from Sigma-Aldrich except for 4-amino-3,5-bis(4-pyridyl)-1,2,4-triazole (bpt), which was prepared following a literature procedure. Solvents were not dried and may thus contain some water.

elements.content: Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) was performed using a TGA Q500 instrument with samples heated at a heating rate of 10 °C min–1 in the temperature range 25–350 °C, under a dry nitrogen flow of 60 mL min–1. Approximately 3–4 mg of sample was placed in an open crucible for each analysis. Powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) measurements were performed on a Bruker D8 Advance X-ray diffractometer in the 4–40° 2θ range using a 0.02° step size per second and X-rays generated at 30 kV and 40 mA. Experimentally obtained PXRD patterns were compared to the simulated PXRD patterns calculated from the respective single crystal structure coordinates using MERCURY.
elements.clean_text: Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) was performed using a TGA Q500 instrument with samples heated at a heating rate of 10 °C min-1 in the temperature range 25-350 °C, under a dry nitrogen flow of 60 mL min-1. Approximately 3-4 mg of sample was placed in an open crucible for each analysis. Powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) measurements were performed on a Bruker D8 Advance X-ray diffractometer in the 4-40° 2θ range using a 0.02° step size per second and X-rays generated at 30 kV and 40 mA. Experimentally obtained PXRD patterns were compared to the simulated PXRD patterns calculated from the respective single crystal structure coordinates using MERCURY.

elements.content: The gas and water vapor sorption experiments were performed using a Micromeritics 3Flex surface area analyzer. The sample was prepared by using a Micromeritics Flowprep with the flow of nitrogen over the sample for 4 h while being heated at 60 °C. Furthermore, the sample was heated at 150 °C under a vacuum in situ for another 2 h before the analysis commenced.

Furthermore, the sample was heated at 150 °C under a vacuum in situ for another 2 h before the analysis commenced.

elements.content: 4,4′-(Hexafluoroisopropylidene)­bis­(benzoic acid) (H2hfipbb) (38 mg, 0.1 mmol) and 4-amino-3,5-bis­(4-pyridyl)-1,2,4-triazole (bpt) (12 mg, 0.05 mmol) were dissolved in 3 mL of N,N′-dimethylformamide (DMF). In a separate vial, zinc nitrate hexahydrate (30 mg, 0.1 mmol) was dissolved in 1 mL of DMF. Both solutions were warmed with stirring, and the resulting clear solutions were mixed together in a Teflon-lined stainless-steel autoclave. The autoclaves were heated under autogenous pressure to 90 °C for 3 days, after which it was allowed to cool slowly to room temperature, yielding prismatic, colorless crystals of 1.
elements.clean_text:
Preparation of [Zn(hfipbb)(bpt)] n ⋅n(DMF)2⋅n(H2O) (1)

4,4'-(Hexafluoroisopropylidene)bis(benzoic acid) (H2hfipbb) (38 mg, 0.1 mmol) and 4-amino-3,5-bis(4-pyridyl)-1,2,4-triazole (bpt) (12 mg, 0.05 mmol) were dissolved in 3 mL of N,N'-dimethylformamide (DMF). In a separate vial, zinc nitrate hexahydrate (30 mg, 0.1 mmol) was dissolved in 1 mL of DMF. Both solutions were warmed with stirring, and the resulting clear solutions were mixed together in a Teflon-lined stainless-steel autoclave. The autoclaves were heated under autogenous pressure to 90 °C for 3 days, after which it was allowed to cool slowly to room temperature, yielding prismatic, colorless crystals of 1.

elements.content:
Freshly synthesized crystals of 1 were dipped into ethanol (EtOH) in a capped vial for 2–3 days at ambient temperature to obtain colorless crystals of 2 through a SCSC transformation.

Preparation of [Zn­(hfipbb)­(bpt)]<sub> <italic>n</italic> </sub>·<italic>n</italic>(DCM)<sub>2</sub>·<italic>n</italic>(H<sub>2</sub>O) (<bold>3</bold>)

Freshly synthesized crystals of 1 were immersed into dichloromethane (DCM) in a capped vial for 12 h at ambient temperature to obtain colorless crystals of 3 with significant fracturing of the crystals. Despite this, a single crystal structure could be determined to unequivocally establish chemical connectivity and solvent content; however, the refined structure suffered from high R-factors.
elements.clean_text:
Preparation of [Zn(hfipbb)(bpt)] n ⋅n(EtOH)2 (2)

Freshly synthesized crystals of 1 were dipped into ethanol (EtOH) in a capped vial for 2-3 days at ambient temperature to obtain colorless crystals of 2 through a SCSC transformation.

Preparation of [Zn(hfipbb)(bpt)] n ⋅n(DCM)2⋅n(H2O) (3)

Freshly synthesized crystals of 1 were immersed into dichloromethane (DCM) in a capped vial for 12 h at ambient temperature to obtain colorless crystals of 3 with significant fracturing of the crystals. Despite this, a single crystal structure could be determined to unequivocally establish chemical connectivity and solvent content; however, the refined structure suffered from high R-factors.

elements.content: Crystals of 4 can be obtained by two different methods. SCSC transformation by submerging crystals of 1 in dimethylacetamide (DMA) occurs over a period of 30–40 days at ambient temperature. Alternatively, crystals of 4 can be obtained directly by heating of the starting materials in an autoclave reaction identical to the reaction conditions of synthesizing 1, except that DMA was used as the solvent and that crystals are obtained only after 50–60 days.

Alternatively, crystals of 4 can be obtained directly by heating of the starting materials in an autoclave reaction identical to the reaction conditions of synthesizing 1, except that DMA was used as the solvent and that crystals are obtained only after 50-60 days.

elements.content:
Crystals of 3 that remained in contact with DCM solvent in a vial at room temperature for 2–3 days led to the formation of crystals of 5.

Single Crystal X-ray Diffraction Studies

Single crystals of suitable quality were selected and mounted using cryoloop in Paratone N oil. Data collections were carried out on Bruker DUO APEX II CCD diffractometer using graphite monochromated MoKα (λ = 0.71073 Å) radiation, generated at 50 kV and 30 mA, with the crystals cooled to 100 K using an Oxford Cryostream-700. Data reduction and unit cell refinement were performed using SAINT-Plus. All intensity data were scaled and corrected for Lorentz-polarization and absorption effects using SADABS. Structure solution and refinement were implemented using the crystallographic suite OLEX2. The crystal structures were solved by SHELXT, with subsequent refinement proceeding using the full full-matrix least-square method, based on F2 values against all reflections, including anisotropic displacement parameters for all non-H atoms, as employed in SHELXL-2018/3. Hydrogen atoms on carbon parent atoms were placed using riding models (Csp2–H: 0.95 Å, U iso(H) = 1.2U eq(C); Csp3–H: 0.98 Å, U iso(H) = 1.5U eq(C)). Amine and water hydrogen atoms were located from electron density maps and restrained with riding models (N–H: 0.88 Å, U iso(H) = 1.2U eq(N); O–H: 0.87 Å, U iso(H) = 1.5U eq(O)). X-Seed and MERCURY were used for generating high-quality images using POV-RAY, while MERCURY was also used to determine void spaces using a probe radius of 1.2 Å.

Crystals of 3 that remained in contact with DCM solvent in a vial at room temperature for 2-3 days led to the formation of crystals of 5.

Single Crystal X-ray Diffraction Studies

Single crystals of suitable quality were selected and mounted using cryoloop in Paratone N oil. Data collections were carried out on Bruker DUO APEX II CCD diffractometer using graphite monochromated MoKα (λ = 0.71073 Å) radiation, generated at 50 kV and 30 mA, with the crystals cooled to 100 K using an Oxford Cryostream-700. Data reduction and unit cell refinement were performed using SAINT-Plus. All intensity data were scaled and corrected for Lorentz-polarization and absorption effects using SADABS. Structure solution and refinement were implemented using the crystallographic suite OLEX2. The crystal structures were solved by SHELXT, with subsequent refinement proceeding using the full full-matrix least-square method, based on F2 values against all reflections, including anisotropic displacement parameters for all non-H atoms, as employed in SHELXL-2018/3. Hydrogen atoms on carbon parent atoms were placed using riding models (Csp2-H: 0.95 Å, U iso(H) = 1.2U eq(C); Csp3-H: 0.98 Å, U iso(H) = 1.5U eq(C)). Amine and water hydrogen atoms were located from electron density maps and restrained with riding models (N-H: 0.88 Å, U iso(H) = 1.2U eq(N); O-H: 0.87 Å, U iso(H) = 1.5U eq(O)). X-Seed and MERCURY were used for generating high-quality images using POV-RAY, while MERCURY was also used to determine void spaces using a probe radius of 1.2 Å.

elements.content: Single crystal X-ray diffraction studies reveal that all the compounds have similar unit cell parameters and belong to the monoclinic space group P21/c (). The asymmetric unit (ASU) of 1 consists of one Zn­(II) ion, one fully deprotonated 4,4′-(hexafluoroisopropylidene)­bis­(benzoic acid) (hfipbb) ligand, one neutral pyridyl-based 4-amino-3,5-bis­(4-pyridyl)-1,2,4-triazole (bpt) coligand, two uncoordinated DMF molecules, and one uncoordinated water molecule (). The Zn­(II) ion exhibits a penta-coordinated, distorted, trigonal bipyramidal (TBP) geometry resulting from coordination to two oxygen atoms (O1 and O2) of a bidentate carboxylate group, one monodentate carboxylate group oxygen atom (O4), one nitrogen atom (N1) from the pyridyl donor that occupies the equatorial position, and, last, one nitrogen atom (N6) in the axial position. The Zn–O distances range from 1.936(2) to 2.413(3) Å, which is comparable to these distances reported for Zn-based coordination polymers. The 2+ charge on the zinc ion is counter balanced by the 2-charge of the fully deprotonated hfipbb ligand. The hfipbb and bpt ligands connect Zn2+ ions along the a- and b-axes, respectively, forming a zigzag, undulated sql square grid 2-periodic network, which stacks in pairs (one pair per unit cell) along the c-axis in an −ABAB– fashion (a). These channels have a potential void space of 29.7% per unit cell if the solvent molecules’ coordinates are deleted (b). Two consecutive 2-periodic layers are stitched together via both direct interlayer hydrogen bonds involving the amine functional group of one layer and carboxylate groups of a neighboring layer (N5–H5A···O1 and N5–H5A···O3), as well as indirectly via consecutive framework–solvent, solvent–solvent, and solvent–framework interactions (N5–H5B···O2S, O1W–H1WA···O2S and O1W–H1WB···N3) which support the 3D supramolecular structure (Supporting Information, Table S1).

Results and Discussion

Single crystal X-ray diffraction studies reveal that all the compounds have similar unit cell parameters and belong to the monoclinic space group P21/c (). The asymmetric unit (ASU) of 1 consists of one Zn(II) ion, one fully deprotonated 4,4'-(hexafluoroisopropylidene)bis(benzoic acid) (hfipbb) ligand, one neutral pyridyl-based 4-amino-3,5-bis(4-pyridyl)-1,2,4-triazole (bpt) coligand, two uncoordinated DMF molecules, and one uncoordinated water molecule (). The Zn(II) ion exhibits a penta-coordinated, distorted, trigonal bipyramidal (TBP) geometry resulting from coordination to two oxygen atoms (O1 and O2) of a bidentate carboxylate group, one monodentate carboxylate group oxygen atom (O4), one nitrogen atom (N1) from the pyridyl donor that occupies the equatorial position, and, last, one nitrogen atom (N6) in the axial position. The Zn-O distances range from 1.936(2) to 2.413(3) Å, which is comparable to these distances reported for Zn-based coordination polymers. The 2+ charge on the zinc ion is counter balanced by the 2-charge of the fully deprotonated hfipbb ligand. The hfipbb and bpt ligands connect Zn2+ ions along the a- and b-axes, respectively, forming a zigzag, undulated  sql  square grid 2-periodic network, which stacks in pairs (one pair per unit cell) along the c-axis in an -ABAB- fashion (a). These channels have a potential void space of 29.7% per unit cell if the solvent molecules' coordinates are deleted (b). Two consecutive 2-periodic layers are stitched together via both direct interlayer hydrogen bonds involving the amine functional group of one layer and carboxylate groups of a neighboring layer (N5-H5A⋅⋅⋅O1 and N5-H5A⋅⋅⋅O3), as well as indirectly via consecutive framework-solvent, solvent-solvent, and solvent-framework interactions (N5-H5B⋅⋅⋅O2S, O1W-H1WA⋅⋅⋅O2S and O1W-H1WB⋅⋅⋅N3) which support the 3D supramolecular structure (Supporting Information, Table S1).

elements.content: It was possible to exchange DMF in 1 with ethanol (2), dichloromethane (3), or dimethylacetamide (4) via SCSC transformations. In addition, a MOF containing only water (5) was obtained after 2–3 days from crystals of 3. In 2, two uncoordinated ethanol molecules per ASU were modeled in the cavities of the framework (a), while the highest residual electron density peak, possibly indicative of a water molecule, was not modeled due to its low density of 0.72 e Å−3. The potential void space (28.9%) is slightly smaller than that of 1 (29.7%) due to the occupation of two solvent molecules per ASU as opposed to the three molecules per ASU found in 1. This is also reflected in the unit cell volume decrease from 3678 Å3 in 1 to 3608 Å3 in 2. Although the framework structure of 3 is quite similar to that of 1 and 2, the binding mode of the hfipbb ligand toward the Zn2+ ion is slightly altered in that both carboxylate groups now bind in a bidentate fashion, resulting in a hexa-coordinated, distorted, trigonal antiprismatic coordination geometry (b). The potential void space increased to 30.7% with two DCM molecules (one DCM molecule is disordered over two positions) and one water molecule per ASU found in the cavities, while the unit cell volume increased to 3792 Å3. In 4, two uncoordinated DMA and two water molecules per ASU are found in the cavities with this structure having the largest potential void space (35.4%) and unit cell volume (3865 Å3). On the contrary, compound 5, with its three unique water molecules per ASU occupying the cavities (one water molecule is disordered over three positions), has less than half the potential void space (15.2%) of 4, and its unit cell volume of 3284 Å3 is also the smallest in this series of framework solvates (15% smaller than that of 4). The structures of 4 and 5 represent the extremities of the “breathing” behavior of the 2-periodic framework in this series of MOFs, exemplified through a number of structural differences. First, in 4 the Zn­(II) ion coordination environment has a penta-coordinate TBP geometry with the noncoordinating O3 atom (of the monodentate carboxylate group) to Zn­(II) ion distance being 2.933(3) Å, while the out-of-plane rotation (relative to the aromatic ring) of the carboxylate group being 19.1°, as defined by torsion angle C13–C14–C17–O3. In 5, the O3 to Zn distance is significantly shorter at 2.070(6) Å, and the corresponding out of plane torsion angle is −4.9°, resulting in a bidentate ligation and a hexa-coordinate Zn­(II) ion environment with trigonal antiprismatic geometry. Second, in 4 the potential void space is represented by parallel channels along the c-axis (a), while in 5 the void space consists of isolated cavities (b). This breathing ability of the framework is also illustrated by the b-axis of 5, which at 15.644 Å, is 4.602 Å shorter than the b-axis of 4. This is nearly as large a change in axis length as was observed for the biggest change in unit cell axis length of the archetypal breathing MOF MIL-53 (5.189 Å). This contraction is along the direction that the bpt ligands have a zigzag coordination with the Zn­(II) ions, with three consecutive Zn­(II) ions along this direction (i.e., the Zn···Zn···Zn angle) having an angle of 88° and 66° in 4 and 5, respectively. The reduction of nearly 22° of this angle in 5 (c) causes the channels to be “pinched off” along the c-axis, leading to the formation of discrete voids. Interestingly, the N–Zn–N coordination angles in 4 and 5 are 99° and 90°, respectively, indicating that this change is not solely responsible for the differences in Zn···Zn···Zn angles. The angle of ligation, i.e., the angle that the pyridyl rings make with the N–Zn bond, also contributes to the Zn···Zn···Zn angle difference in 4 and 5. The change along the hfipbb direction of ligation (a-axis) is minimal at 0.024 Å, while in 5 the c-axis (the stacking direction of the layers) is longer by 1.167 Å, despite having the smaller potential void space and unit cell volume.

Solvent Exchange Studies

It was possible to exchange DMF in 1 with ethanol (2), dichloromethane (3), or dimethylacetamide (4) via SCSC transformations. In addition, a MOF containing only water (5) was obtained after 2-3 days from crystals of 3. In 2, two uncoordinated ethanol molecules per ASU were modeled in the cavities of the framework (a), while the highest residual electron density peak, possibly indicative of a water molecule, was not modeled due to its low density of 0.72 e Å-3. The potential void space (28.9%) is slightly smaller than that of 1 (29.7%) due to the occupation of two solvent molecules per ASU as opposed to the three molecules per ASU found in 1. This is also reflected in the unit cell volume decrease from 3678 Å3 in 1 to 3608 Å3 in 2. Although the framework structure of 3 is quite similar to that of 1 and 2, the binding mode of the hfipbb ligand toward the Zn2+ ion is slightly altered in that both carboxylate groups now bind in a bidentate fashion, resulting in a hexa-coordinated, distorted, trigonal antiprismatic coordination geometry (b). The potential void space increased to 30.7% with two DCM molecules (one DCM molecule is disordered over two positions) and one water molecule per ASU found in the cavities, while the unit cell volume increased to 3792 Å3. In 4, two uncoordinated DMA and two water molecules per ASU are found in the cavities with this structure having the largest potential void space (35.4%) and unit cell volume (3865 Å3). On the contrary, compound 5, with its three unique water molecules per ASU occupying the cavities (one water molecule is disordered over three positions), has less than half the potential void space (15.2%) of 4, and its unit cell volume of 3284 Å3 is also the smallest in this series of framework solvates (15% smaller than that of 4). The structures of 4 and 5 represent the extremities of the "breathing" behavior of the 2-periodic framework in this series of MOFs, exemplified through a number of structural differences. First, in 4 the Zn(II) ion coordination environment has a penta-coordinate TBP geometry with the noncoordinating O3 atom (of the monodentate carboxylate group) to Zn(II) ion distance being 2.933(3) Å, while the out-of-plane rotation (relative to the aromatic ring) of the carboxylate group being 19.1°, as defined by torsion angle C13-C14-C17-O3. In 5, the O3 to Zn distance is significantly shorter at 2.070(6) Å, and the corresponding out of plane torsion angle is -4.9°, resulting in a bidentate ligation and a hexa-coordinate Zn(II) ion environment with trigonal antiprismatic geometry. Second, in 4 the potential void space is represented by parallel channels along the c-axis (a), while in 5 the void space consists of isolated cavities (b). This breathing ability of the framework is also illustrated by the b-axis of 5, which at 15.644 Å, is 4.602 Å shorter than the b-axis of 4. This is nearly as large a change in axis length as was observed for the biggest change in unit cell axis length of the archetypal breathing MOF MIL-53 (5.189 Å). This contraction is along the direction that the bpt ligands have a zigzag coordination with the Zn(II) ions, with three consecutive Zn(II) ions along this direction (i.e., the Zn⋅⋅⋅Zn⋅⋅⋅Zn angle) having an angle of 88° and 66° in 4 and 5, respectively. The reduction of nearly 22° of this angle in 5 (c) causes the channels to be "pinched off" along the c-axis, leading to the formation of discrete voids. Interestingly, the N-Zn-N coordination angles in 4 and 5 are 99° and 90°, respectively, indicating that this change is not solely responsible for the differences in Zn⋅⋅⋅Zn⋅⋅⋅Zn angles. The angle of ligation, i.e., the angle that the pyridyl rings make with the N-Zn bond, also contributes to the Zn⋅⋅⋅Zn⋅⋅⋅Zn angle difference in 4 and 5. The change along the hfipbb direction of ligation (a-axis) is minimal at 0.024 Å, while in 5 the c-axis (the stacking direction of the layers) is longer by 1.167 Å, despite having the smaller potential void space and unit cell volume.

elements.content: The TGA thermograms of 1, 2 and 3 shows a mass losses of 20.4% (calc. 19.1%), 13.1% (calc. 12.5%), and 21.8% (calc. 21.3%) from room temperature (∼20 °C) at the start of the analyses to 250 °C. Compounds 1, 2, and 3 all have their largest mass losses before 150 °C, followed by a smaller mass loss up to 250 °C (Figure S2a–c) and eventual framework decomposition at ∼350 °C. This suggests that the organic solvent molecules are lost first followed by the loss of the remaining water molecules (even in the case of 2 a small amount of unmodelled water seems to be present). This is consistent with the fact that compound 5 (containing water only) was obtained from compound 3 (containing DCM and water), the former having the smallest unit cell volume and potential void space.
elements.clean_text:
Thermal Analysis

The TGA thermograms of 1, 2 and 3 shows a mass losses of 20.4% (calc. 19.1%), 13.1% (calc. 12.5%), and 21.8% (calc. 21.3%) from room temperature (~20 °C) at the start of the analyses to 250 °C. Compounds 1, 2, and 3 all have their largest mass losses before 150 °C, followed by a smaller mass loss up to 250 °C (Figure S2a-c) and eventual framework decomposition at ~350 °C. This suggests that the organic solvent molecules are lost first followed by the loss of the remaining water molecules (even in the case of 2 a small amount of unmodelled water seems to be present). This is consistent with the fact that compound 5 (containing water only) was obtained from compound 3 (containing DCM and water), the former having the smallest unit cell volume and potential void space.

elements.content: VT-PXRD patterns were recorded to establish the structural behavior of the various MOF solvates during activation for gas and vapor sorption studies. The PXRD pattern of 1 at room temperature and ambient pressure (open chamber–no vacuum) matches very well with the calculated pattern of 1 at 100 K, which further confirms that the single crystal structure represents the corresponding bulk material (). The variable temperature experiments with a vacuum indicate the removal of solvent starts immediately at 25 °C, as indicated by changes in the pattern. The VT-PXRD patterns from 50–150 °C are increasingly similar to that of the calculated pattern for 5, indicating that the framework structure of 1, upon desolvation, starts conforming to that of 5. The peak at 9.3° 2θ decreases significantly (and more so at higher temperatures), while new peaks appear at 10.9°, 13.0°, and 24.8° 2θ.
elements.clean_text:
Variable-Temperature Powder X-ray Diffraction (VT-PXRD) Studies

VT-PXRD patterns were recorded to establish the structural behavior of the various MOF solvates during activation for gas and vapor sorption studies. The PXRD pattern of 1 at room temperature and ambient pressure (open chamber-no vacuum) matches very well with the calculated pattern of 1 at 100 K, which further confirms that the single crystal structure represents the corresponding bulk material (). The variable temperature experiments with a vacuum indicate the removal of solvent starts immediately at 25 °C, as indicated by changes in the pattern. The VT-PXRD patterns from 50-150 °C are increasingly similar to that of the calculated pattern for 5, indicating that the framework structure of 1, upon desolvation, starts conforming to that of 5. The peak at 9.3° 2θ decreases significantly (and more so at higher temperatures), while new peaks appear at 10.9°, 13.0°, and 24.8° 2θ.

elements.content: Upon desolvation, compounds 1, 2, and 3 are transformed to an evacuated framework that resembles quite closely the structure of compound 5 as was established from VT-PXRD studies. Therefore, only compound 1 was desolvated to prepare an “activated” framework (hereinafter 1′) for testing nitrogen, hydrogen, and carbon dioxide gas sorption as well as water vapor sorption. Nitrogen sorption was negligible at 77 K, while carbon dioxide isotherms at various temperatures displayed type-I sorption behavior with no hysteresis. At 273 K, carbon dioxide sorption was 21.4 cm3 (STP) g–1 at an absolute pressure of 784 mmHg (0.66 CO2 molecules per ASU), while at 195 K, it more than doubles to 53.6 cm3 (STP) g–1 at an absolute pressure of 710 mmHg (1.66 CO2 molecules per ASU). The ability of carbon dioxide to adsorb selectively over nitrogen could be ascribed to its larger quadrupole moment (−1.4 × 10–39 C m2 for CO2 vs −4.7 × 10–40 C m2 for N2), allowing the structure to open up through a “gate opening” mechanism by rotation of the pyridyl or triazole moieties of the bpt ligand. The breathing behavior, and the accompanying structural changes, were illustrated in , but it is also evident that the conformations of the bpt ligands in 4 and 5 are not the same (c). Interestingly, none of the curves display an inflection point, which is typically associated with “gate-opening” behavior. We suggest that at higher pressures this inflection point may be observed as the structure could adsorb more than the maximum sorption of 1.66 CO2 molecules that we observed at 195 K, since 4 contained four solvent molecules per ASU, two of which (DMA) are larger than CO2. In the absence of nitrogen sorption, CO2 sorption at 273 K reveals a modest surface area of 77 m2 g–1. Although the use of CO2 sorption for BET calculations is controversial, Bae et al. showed that it may be used for ultra-microporous materials at 273 K. Carbon dioxide isotherms between 273 and 298 K revealed isosteric heats of adsorption (Q st) values of 33.6–35.8 kJ mol–1 at load values ranging from 0.22–0.60 mmol g–1 (Figure S3), indicating a moderate to strong interaction of CO2 with 1′. Hydrogen gas uptake was 48.5 cm3 g–1 at 800 mmHg and 77 K, corresponding to sorption of 0.44 wt % (2.16 mmol g–1 and 1.50 H2 molecules per ASU) with significant positive hysteresis. ­().
elements.clean_text:
Gas and Vapor Sorption Studies

Upon desolvation, compounds 1, 2, and 3 are transformed to an evacuated framework that resembles quite closely the structure of compound 5 as was established from VT-PXRD studies. Therefore, only compound 1 was desolvated to prepare an "activated" framework (hereinafter 1') for testing nitrogen, hydrogen, and carbon dioxide gas sorption as well as water vapor sorption. Nitrogen sorption was negligible at 77 K, while carbon dioxide isotherms at various temperatures displayed type-I sorption behavior with no hysteresis. At 273 K, carbon dioxide sorption was 21.4 cm3 (STP) g-1 at an absolute pressure of 784 mmHg (0.66 CO2 molecules per ASU), while at 195 K, it more than doubles to 53.6 cm3 (STP) g-1 at an absolute pressure of 710 mmHg (1.66 CO2 molecules per ASU). The ability of carbon dioxide to adsorb selectively over nitrogen could be ascribed to its larger quadrupole moment (-1.4 × 10-39 C m2 for CO2 vs -4.7 × 10-40 C m2 for N2), allowing the structure to open up through a "gate opening" mechanism by rotation of the pyridyl or triazole moieties of the bpt ligand. The breathing behavior, and the accompanying structural changes, were illustrated in , but it is also evident that the conformations of the bpt ligands in 4 and 5 are not the same (c). Interestingly, none of the curves display an inflection point, which is typically associated with "gate-opening" behavior. We suggest that at higher pressures this inflection point may be observed as the structure could adsorb more than the maximum sorption of 1.66 CO2 molecules that we observed at 195 K, since 4 contained four solvent molecules per ASU, two of which (DMA) are larger than CO2. In the absence of nitrogen sorption, CO2 sorption at 273 K reveals a modest surface area of 77 m2 g-1. Although the use of CO2 sorption for BET calculations is controversial, Bae et al. showed that it may be used for ultra-microporous materials at 273 K. Carbon dioxide isotherms between 273 and 298 K revealed isosteric heats of adsorption (Q st) values of 33.6-35.8 kJ mol-1 at load values ranging from 0.22-0.60 mmol g-1 (Figure S3), indicating a moderate to strong interaction of CO2 with 1'. Hydrogen gas uptake was 48.5 cm3 g-1 at 800 mmHg and 77 K, corresponding to sorption of 0.44 wt % (2.16 mmol g-1 and 1.50 H2 molecules per ASU) with significant positive hysteresis. ().

elements.content: Although the H2 adsorption for this compound is somewhat moderate, it is still comparable in the range for several other MOFs reported in the literature; however, the displayed hysteretic behavior is rare. Bharadwaj et al. have reported Zn­(II)-based mixed-ligand MOFs with bpt and tris­(4′-carboxybiphenyl)­amine as ligands where one of the activated forms had a large void space of 61.0% and a surface area of 340 m2 g–1, values that are considerably larger than for 1′, yet its hydrogen sorption values compares well with those reported for the Bharadwaj MOF. This could be explained by the presence of the trifluoromethyl groups which decorate the channels in 1′. Compound 1 also displayed a high affinity for water vapor (). The amount of water adsorbed at relative pressure P/P o of 0.76 at 298 K is 67.3 cm3 (STP) g–1 that corresponds to 1.82 molecules of H2O per ASU. As in the case of hydrogen sorption, a hysteretic sorption behavior was observed.

elements.content: In summary, a mixed-ligand, partially fluorinated, 2-periodic MOF [Zn­(hfipbb)­(bpt)] n ­·n(DMF)2­·n(H2O) (1) has been synthesized from the unique combination of the V-shaped dicarboxylic acid ligand 4,4′-(hexafluoroisopropylidene)­bis­(benzoic acid) and another bent ligand, the pyridyl-based colinker 4-amino-3,5-bis­(4-pyridyl)-1,2,4-triazole, representing the first combination of the latter ligand with a fluorinated ligand in a MOF. This framework displays solvent-induced breathing behavior by undergoing single-crystal-to-single-crystal solvent exchange with ethanol, dichloromethane, and dimethylacetamide that leads to the formation of four additional structures, showing a large variation in their potential void spaces. The hfipbb ligand provides rigidity along one dimension (apart from the rotation of one carboxylate group) of the 2-periodic network, while the bpt ligand, through the angle of ligation and conformational changes, facilitates the contraction and expansion of the framework. The activated phase of 1 shows appreciable carbon dioxide sorption at 195 K and hydrogen at 77 K, as well as water vapor at 298 K. The lack of an inflection point in the isotherms may indicate that the framework may still “open” up some more upon exposure to higher carbon dioxide pressures.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusion

In summary, a mixed-ligand, partially fluorinated, 2-periodic MOF [Zn(hfipbb)(bpt)] n ⋅n(DMF)2⋅n(H2O) (1) has been synthesized from the unique combination of the V-shaped dicarboxylic acid ligand 4,4'-(hexafluoroisopropylidene)bis(benzoic acid) and another bent ligand, the pyridyl-based colinker 4-amino-3,5-bis(4-pyridyl)-1,2,4-triazole, representing the first combination of the latter ligand with a fluorinated ligand in a MOF. This framework displays solvent-induced breathing behavior by undergoing single-crystal-to-single-crystal solvent exchange with ethanol, dichloromethane, and dimethylacetamide that leads to the formation of four additional structures, showing a large variation in their potential void spaces. The hfipbb ligand provides rigidity along one dimension (apart from the rotation of one carboxylate group) of the 2-periodic network, while the bpt ligand, through the angle of ligation and conformational changes, facilitates the contraction and expansion of the framework. The activated phase of 1 shows appreciable carbon dioxide sorption at 195 K and hydrogen at 77 K, as well as water vapor at 298 K. The lack of an inflection point in the isotherms may indicate that the framework may still "open" up some more upon exposure to higher carbon dioxide pressures.

The Supporting Information is available free of charge on the ACS Publications website at DOI: 10.1021/acs.cgd.8b01391.

General synthesis procedures, structural and thermal analysis of MOFs such as variable temperature powder X-ray diffraction (VT-PXRD) and thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) are included along with the table of selected hydrogen bonding interactions in different frameworks. The heat of adsorption plot and report based on isotherms for carbon dioxide sorption of activated 1 at different temperatures have also been tabulated (PDF)

cln_elements.content: 4,4′-(Hexafluoroisopropylidene)­bis­(benzoic acid) (H2hfipbb) (38 mg, 0.1 mmol) and 4-amino-3,5-bis­(4-pyridyl)-1,2,4-triazole (bpt) (12 mg, 0.05 mmol) were dissolved in 3 mL of N,N′-dimethylformamide (DMF). In a separate vial, zinc nitrate hexahydrate (30 mg, 0.1 mmol) was dissolved in 1 mL of DMF. Both solutions were warmed with stirring, and the resulting clear solutions were mixed together in a Teflon-lined stainless-steel autoclave. The autoclaves were heated under autogenous pressure to 90 °C for 3 days, after which it was allowed to cool slowly to room temperature, yielding prismatic, colorless crystals of 1.
cln_elements.clean_text:
Preparation of [Zn(hfipbb)(bpt)] n ⋅n(DMF)2⋅n(H2O) (1)

4,4'-(Hexafluoroisopropylidene)bis(benzoic acid) (H2hfipbb) (38 mg, 0.1 mmol) and 4-amino-3,5-bis(4-pyridyl)-1,2,4-triazole (bpt) (12 mg, 0.05 mmol) were dissolved in 3 mL of N,N'-dimethylformamide (DMF). In a separate vial, zinc nitrate hexahydrate (30 mg, 0.1 mmol) was dissolved in 1 mL of DMF. Both solutions were warmed with stirring, and the resulting clear solutions were mixed together in a Teflon-lined stainless-steel autoclave. The autoclaves were heated under autogenous pressure to 90 °C for 3 days, after which it was allowed to cool slowly to room temperature, yielding prismatic, colorless crystals of 1.

cln_elements.content:
The TGA thermograms of 1, 2 and 3 shows a mass losses of 20.4% (calc. 19.1%), 13.1% (calc. 12.5%), and 21.8% (calc. 21.3%) from room temperature (∼20 °C) at the start of the analyses to 250 °C. Compounds 1, 2, and 3 all have their largest mass losses before 150 °C, followed by a smaller mass loss up to 250 °C (Figure S2a–c) and eventual framework decomposition at ∼350 °C. This suggests that the organic solvent molecules are lost first followed by the loss of the remaining water molecules (even in the case of 2 a small amount of unmodelled water seems to be present). This is consistent with the fact that compound 5 (containing water only) was obtained from compound 3 (containing DCM and water), the former having the smallest unit cell volume and potential void space.

Variable-Temperature Powder X-ray Diffraction (VT-PXRD) Studies

VT-PXRD patterns were recorded to establish the structural behavior of the various MOF solvates during activation for gas and vapor sorption studies. The PXRD pattern of 1 at room temperature and ambient pressure (open chamber–no vacuum) matches very well with the calculated pattern of 1 at 100 K, which further confirms that the single crystal structure represents the corresponding bulk material (). The variable temperature experiments with a vacuum indicate the removal of solvent starts immediately at 25 °C, as indicated by changes in the pattern. The VT-PXRD patterns from 50–150 °C are increasingly similar to that of the calculated pattern for 5, indicating that the framework structure of 1, upon desolvation, starts conforming to that of 5. The peak at 9.3° 2θ decreases significantly (and more so at higher temperatures), while new peaks appear at 10.9°, 13.0°, and 24.8° 2θ.

Gas and Vapor Sorption Studies

Upon desolvation, compounds 1, 2, and 3 are transformed to an evacuated framework that resembles quite closely the structure of compound 5 as was established from VT-PXRD studies. Therefore, only compound 1 was desolvated to prepare an “activated” framework (hereinafter 1′) for testing nitrogen, hydrogen, and carbon dioxide gas sorption as well as water vapor sorption. Nitrogen sorption was negligible at 77 K, while carbon dioxide isotherms at various temperatures displayed type-I sorption behavior with no hysteresis. At 273 K, carbon dioxide sorption was 21.4 cm3 (STP) g–1 at an absolute pressure of 784 mmHg (0.66 CO2 molecules per ASU), while at 195 K, it more than doubles to 53.6 cm3 (STP) g–1 at an absolute pressure of 710 mmHg (1.66 CO2 molecules per ASU). The ability of carbon dioxide to adsorb selectively over nitrogen could be ascribed to its larger quadrupole moment (−1.4 × 10–39 C m2 for CO2 vs −4.7 × 10–40 C m2 for N2), allowing the structure to open up through a “gate opening” mechanism by rotation of the pyridyl or triazole moieties of the bpt ligand. The breathing behavior, and the accompanying structural changes, were illustrated in , but it is also evident that the conformations of the bpt ligands in 4 and 5 are not the same (c). Interestingly, none of the curves display an inflection point, which is typically associated with “gate-opening” behavior. We suggest that at higher pressures this inflection point may be observed as the structure could adsorb more than the maximum sorption of 1.66 CO2 molecules that we observed at 195 K, since 4 contained four solvent molecules per ASU, two of which (DMA) are larger than CO2. In the absence of nitrogen sorption, CO2 sorption at 273 K reveals a modest surface area of 77 m2 g–1. Although the use of CO2 sorption for BET calculations is controversial, Bae et al. showed that it may be used for ultra-microporous materials at 273 K. Carbon dioxide isotherms between 273 and 298 K revealed isosteric heats of adsorption (Q st) values of 33.6–35.8 kJ mol–1 at load values ranging from 0.22–0.60 mmol g–1 (Figure S3), indicating a moderate to strong interaction of CO2 with 1′. Hydrogen gas uptake was 48.5 cm3 g–1 at 800 mmHg and 77 K, corresponding to sorption of 0.44 wt % (2.16 mmol g–1 and 1.50 H2 molecules per ASU) with significant positive hysteresis. ­().

Although the H2 adsorption for this compound is somewhat moderate, it is still comparable in the range for several other MOFs reported in the literature; however, the displayed hysteretic behavior is rare. Bharadwaj et al. have reported Zn­(II)-based mixed-ligand MOFs with bpt and tris­(4′-carboxybiphenyl)­amine as ligands where one of the activated forms had a large void space of 61.0% and a surface area of 340 m2 g–1, values that are considerably larger than for 1′, yet its hydrogen sorption values compares well with those reported for the Bharadwaj MOF. This could be explained by the presence of the trifluoromethyl groups which decorate the channels in 1′. Compound 1 also displayed a high affinity for water vapor (). The amount of water adsorbed at relative pressure P/P o of 0.76 at 298 K is 67.3 cm3 (STP) g–1 that corresponds to 1.82 molecules of H2O per ASU. As in the case of hydrogen sorption, a hysteretic sorption behavior was observed.

We suggest that at higher pressures this inflection point may be observed as the structure could adsorb more than the maximum sorption of 1.66 CO2 molecules that we observed at 195 K, since 4 contained four solvent molecules per ASU, two of which (DMA) are larger than CO2. (a) Coordination environment of the Zn­(II) ion in 1 shown with the unique, uncoordinated solvent molecules. Hydrogen atoms are omitted, and only the asymmetric unit is labeled for clarity. (b) Representation of the distorted trigonal bipyramidal (TBP) geometry around the Zn­(II) ion in 1.
cln_elements.clean_text: 1  (a) Coordination environment of the Zn(II) ion in 1 shown with the unique, uncoordinated solvent molecules. Hydrogen atoms are omitted, and only the asymmetric unit is labeled for clarity. (b) Representation of the distorted trigonal bipyramidal (TBP) geometry around the Zn(II) ion in 1.

cln_elements.content: (a) Overall packing of the framework of 1 along the c-axis. Hydrogen atoms and solvent molecules are omitted for clarity. (b) Topological representations of the 2-periodic nets from (top) an oblique angle showing a zigzag pair of undulated sql square grid nets and (bottom) a side-on view showing their interdigitation. The metal centers, the C8 atoms of hfipbb ligands, and the centroids of the triazole rings of the bpt ligands are taken as nodes in this topological representation.
cln_elements.clean_text: 2  (a) Overall packing of the framework of 1 along the c-axis. Hydrogen atoms and solvent molecules are omitted for clarity. (b) Topological representations of the 2-periodic nets from (top) an oblique angle showing a zigzag pair of undulated  sql  square grid nets and (bottom) a side-on view showing their interdigitation. The metal centers, the C8 atoms of hfipbb ligands, and the centroids of the triazole rings of the bpt ligands are taken as nodes in this topological representation.

cln_elements.content: Packing diagram of 1 along the (a) crystallographic a-axis and (b) crystallographic c-axis with the DMF and H2O molecules omitted to show potential void space. Hydrogen atoms on the frameworks are omitted for clarity.
cln_elements.clean_text: 3  Packing diagram of 1 along the (a) crystallographic a-axis and (b) crystallographic c-axis with the DMF and H2O molecules omitted to show potential void space. Hydrogen atoms on the frameworks are omitted for clarity.

cln_elements.content: Coordination environments of Zn­(II) ion in (a) 2, (b) 3, (c) 4, and (d) 5 (peach-colored atoms represent the three disordered positions of the third water molecule). Hydrogen atoms are omitted for clarity and the labeling of atoms of the frameworks are as for 1.
cln_elements.clean_text: 4  Coordination environments of Zn(II) ion in (a) 2, (b) 3, (c) 4, and (d) 5 (peach-colored atoms represent the three disordered positions of the third water molecule). Hydrogen atoms are omitted for clarity and the labeling of atoms of the frameworks are as for 1.

cln_elements.content: (a) Channels of potential void space in 4 (b) and isolated voids in 5. (c) Change in the Zn···Zn···Zn angle between two bpt ligands in the framework with the largest (4 shown in purple) and smallest (5 shown in cyan) void space volumes. The Zn­(II) ions are shown as small spheres in both structures.
